condition.description:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), previously known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a rare disease. It is a type of vasculitis, or inflammation of the blood vessels. The inflammation limits the flow of blood to important organs, causing damage. It can affect any organ, but it mainly affects the sinuses, nose, trachea (windpipe), lungs, and kidneys.

The cause of GPA is unknown. It can affect people at any age. Men and women are equally affected. It is more common in whites. Symptoms may include joint pain, weakness, tiredness, and cold symptoms such as a runny nose that doesn't get better. Doctors use blood tests, chest X-rays, and biopsies to diagnose GPA and rule out other causes of the symptoms.

Early treatment is important. Most people improve with medicines to slow or stop the inflammation.

NIH: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
condition.name: Wegener's granulomatosis

carousel_items: Rituximab is given as an IV infusion by trained medical staff in a clinic or hospital.
You'll need to be monitored in the clinic in case you have a serious or life-threatening reaction during the infusion, but you can take other medications that'll lower your risk of this happening.
It's very important that you read the Medication Guide before you start taking Rituximab.
Rituximab lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, a cough that doesn't go away, or flu-like symptoms.
Use effective birth control while you're taking Rituximab and for 12 months after you finish treatment.
Don't get live vaccines while you're taking Rituximab.

basics.benefits_moa: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody. It targets a specific protein on white blood cells that makes it easier for your immune system to find and destroy cancerous cells. It also relieves symptoms and slows the progression of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
basics.bottom_line: Rituximab is effective for treating multiple types of cancer and arthritis. That said, you'll need to watch for possibly serious side effects, especially infusion reactions.
downsides: Only your doctor or other trained medical staff can administer Rituximab, so you'll need to go into an office or clinic for every dose.
Not the best choice if you have heart problems.
Rituximab can stay in your body for up to 6 months after you complete treatment. Men and women who are able to have children need to use birth control for up to one year after finishing Rituximab.
Discuss with your doctor the serious heart, kidney, liver, or stomach problems that can happen while on Rituximab.

downsides_processed.orig: Only your doctor or other trained medical staff can administer Rituximab, so you'll need to go into an office or clinic for every dose.
Not the best choice if you have heart problems.
Rituximab can stay in your body for up to 6 months after you complete treatment. Men and women who are able to have children need to use birth control for up to one year after finishing Rituximab.
Discuss with your doctor the serious heart, kidney, liver, or stomach problems that can happen while on Rituximab.

upsides: Treats leukemia, lymphoma, and blood vessel inflammation.
Also treats moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis that hasn't responded to anti-TNF treatment (but you'll need to take methotrexate too).

The chance of having a reaction to the infusion is highest during your first dose, but the risk decreases each time you get Rituximab. It usually happens within 30 minutes to 2 hours after starting the infusion.
Rituximab is a targeted therapy that works differently than chemotherapy. Both work well when they're taken together, especially when treating CLL and NHL.

upsides_processed.orig: Treats leukemia, lymphoma, and blood vessel inflammation.
Also treats moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis that hasn't responded to anti-TNF treatment (but you'll need to take methotrexate too).

The chance of having a reaction to the infusion is highest during your first dose, but the risk decreases each time you get Rituximab. It usually happens within 30 minutes to 2 hours after starting the infusion.
Rituximab is a targeted therapy that works differently than chemotherapy. Both work well when they're taken together, especially when treating CLL and NHL.

drugs.name: Rituxan

carousel_items_processed.orig: Rituximab is given as an IV infusion by trained medical staff in a clinic or hospital.
You'll need to be monitored in the clinic in case you have a serious or life-threatening reaction during the infusion, but you can take other medications that'll lower your risk of this happening.
It's very important that you read the Medication Guide before you start taking Rituximab.
Rituximab lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, a cough that doesn't go away, or flu-like symptoms.
Use effective birth control while you're taking Rituximab and for 12 months after you finish treatment.
Don't get live vaccines while you're taking Rituximab.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Serious infusion reactions can occur at the time Rituximab is given and within 24 hours. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if  you notice itching, sudden cough, dizziness, racing heartbeat, chest pain, or  angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose so the risk of having this happen is less.

description_processed.orig: Serious infusion reactions can occur at the time Rituximab is given and within 24 hours. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if  you notice itching, sudden cough, dizziness, racing heartbeat, chest pain, or  angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose so the risk of having this happen is less.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Rituximab can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections including sepsis. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Rituximab. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Rituximab can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections including sepsis. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Rituximab. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Rituximab can cause Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML), a serious often fatal brain infection caused by a virus. Unfortunately, it can't be prevented or treated, and if you get it, there's no cure. Let your doctor know right away if you become confused, dizzy, have vision problems, loss of balance or weakness on one side of your body
risk_factors: Taking Rituximab with immunosuppressant drugs (if using for RA)
Taking Rituximab with chemotherapy (if using for NHL or CLL

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Rituximab can cause Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML), a serious often fatal brain infection caused by a virus. Unfortunately, it can't be prevented or treated, and if you get it, there's no cure. Let your doctor know right away if you become confused, dizzy, have vision problems, loss of balance or weakness on one side of your body

risks_warnings.title: Skin and mouth reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, pemphigus)  can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Rituximab. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips or inside your mouth or peeling skin that's painful. You may not be able to re-start Rituximab after this reaction.

description_processed.orig: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, pemphigus)  can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Rituximab. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips or inside your mouth or peeling skin that's painful. You may not be able to re-start Rituximab after this reaction.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney injury
risks_warnings.description: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) happens when cancer cells are broken down very quickly and damage the kidneys. The damage can be so bad that people need dialysis. If you're taking Rituximab for a cancer condition your doctor can give you medicines and take measures to prevent this reaction.

description_processed.orig: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) happens when cancer cells are broken down very quickly and damage the kidneys. The damage can be so bad that people need dialysis. If you're taking Rituximab for a cancer condition your doctor can give you medicines and take measures to prevent this reaction.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Rituximab can increase your risk of irregular heartbeat. Your doctor may test your heart and blood before starting treatment. If  the heart problems are serious, your doctor may stop Rituximab.

description_processed.orig: Rituximab can increase your risk of irregular heartbeat. Your doctor may test your heart and blood before starting treatment. If  the heart problems are serious, your doctor may stop Rituximab.

risks_warnings.title: Gastrointestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Blockage or tearing of the bowel can happen early on (average is within 6 days) while taking Rituximab. If you develop belly pain with or without repeated vomiting, tell your doctor and get medical help right away.

description_processed.orig: Blockage or tearing of the bowel can happen early on (average is within 6 days) while taking Rituximab. If you develop belly pain with or without repeated vomiting, tell your doctor and get medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Rituximab can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

description_processed.orig: Rituximab can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

carousel_items: Take this medication exactly how your doctor tells you to.
Can make your skin more sensitive to the sun.
Drink plenty of liquids when taking the medication.
Can cause diarrhea, nausea or vomiting.

basics.benefits_moa: Bactrim is a combination antibiotic that contains sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim. It kills bacteria by preventing them from making proteins and other chemicals that keep them alive.
basics.bottom_line: Bactrim is good for treating many bacterial infections and is available as a generic. However, you can be more likely to sunburn. Also, it can cause birth defects, so talk to your doctor if you're pregnant.
downsides: Makes your skin more sensitive to the sun.
Has to be taken with plenty of liquids.

downsides_processed.orig: Makes your skin more sensitive to the sun.
Has to be taken with plenty of liquids.

upsides: Available in different forms: tablet, capsule and suspension.
Used to treat many types of bacterial infections.
Less resistance seen to this antibiotic. Your doctor may run tests to see if Bactrim responds to your infection.

upsides_processed.orig: Available in different forms: tablet, capsule and suspension.
Used to treat many types of bacterial infections.
Less resistance seen to this antibiotic. Your doctor may run tests to see if Bactrim responds to your infection.

userStories.tip: Take probiotics along with this as it upsets the stomach. Also, I find taking it first thing in the morning and just right before bed the best.
I broke the pill in half to take it. It made it easier  to swallow. Definitely stay out of the sun.

userStories.satisfaction: Not worth it, thinking about stopping
userStories.tip: Bactrim put me in a state of constant anxiety after the very first dose. After two days, I refused to take anymore of it.

drugs.name: Bactrim

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take this medication exactly how your doctor tells you to.
Can make your skin more sensitive to the sun.
Drink plenty of liquids when taking the medication.
Can cause diarrhea, nausea or vomiting.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea
risks_warnings.description: As with all antibiotics, Bactrim can cause diarrhea. If this happens while you're taking the medication, taking probiotics in the form of yogurt, supplements or drinks a few hours after you take the medication may help. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor as this can be a rare but serious side effect.

description_processed.orig: As with all antibiotics, Bactrim can cause diarrhea. If this happens while you're taking the medication, taking probiotics in the form of yogurt, supplements or drinks a few hours after you take the medication may help. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor as this can be a rare but serious side effect.

risks_warnings.title: Sunburn
risks_warnings.description: Your skin can be more likely to sunburn while you're on Bactrim. Avoid tanning or tanning beds, and put on sunblock if you have to be out in the sun.

description_processed.orig: Your skin can be more likely to sunburn while you're on Bactrim. Avoid tanning or tanning beds, and put on sunblock if you have to be out in the sun.

risks_warnings.title: Rash
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of severe skin rash that can require hospitalization or can cause death. These have been rare. Talk to your doctor immediately if you suddenly develop a severe blistering skin rash with fever.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of severe skin rash that can require hospitalization or can cause death. These have been rare. Talk to your doctor immediately if you suddenly develop a severe blistering skin rash with fever.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: If you are pregnant, talk to your doctor about alternatives as Bactrim may damage the fetus.

description_processed.orig: If you are pregnant, talk to your doctor about alternatives as Bactrim may damage the fetus.

carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

downsides_processed.orig: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

upsides_processed.orig: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

userStories.tip: Remicade changed my life. Before I started it, I was in constant pain and had a difficult time getting out of a chair or turning over in bed. Now I have only minor pain and live a full and happy life.
Have gotten severe psoriasis from the medication.
Make sure to get lots of rest for the rest of the day. Don't go on a plane within a day or two or you will get sick.
userStories.identifier: early 30s single with 70 hour work week

userStories.tip: I have been in remission since my first dose!

drugs.name: Remicade

carousel_items_processed.orig: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

description_processed.orig: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause serious liver injury. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested regularly. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash you should stop treatment with Remicade until you can be completely assessed,

description_processed.orig: Although rare, Remicade can cause serious liver injury. You'll need to have your liver enzymes tested regularly. If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash you should stop treatment with Remicade until you can be completely assessed,
